newsitem.title: USA: Norfolk Southern reports earnings, sets meeting.
newsitem.headline: Norfolk Southern reports earnings, sets meeting.

text.p: Norfolk Southern Corp. said Wednesday a crucial meeting in the takeover battle for Conrail Inc. has been set for Friday and also reported a 13 percent rise in earnings for the fourth quarter.
Last week executives of Conrail, CSX Corp. and Norfolk Southern agreed to hold discussions about the planned $9.5 billion merger of Conrail and CSX.

First announced in October, the deal has been fraught with troubles due to a rival $10.3 billion bid from Norfolk Southern. Philadelphia-based Conrail has rejected the Norfolk Southern offer, contending that the CSX deal was a better fit.
But earlier this month Conrail shareholders rejected a key measure needed for the CSX transaction to move forward.
Norfolk Southern Chairman David Goode said while it would be "very difficult" he was confident of reaching a solution in the takeover battle.

During a meeting with financial analysts, monitored by telephone, he also reiterated a pledge to obtain for Conrail shareholders a payment of $115 a share in cash. The Conrail-CSX merger calls for a combination of cash and stock.
Goode told the analysts he was pleased Conrail and CSX Corp. had responded positively to his invitation to meet.
"We have set a meeting Friday, and I plan to be there, ready to work hard for a solution" he said.
Some Wall Street experts have speculated that the ultimate conclusion will call for a splitting up of Conrail's assets.
But sources close to Conrail have said its executives would oppose plans to split up the railroad and distribute its pieces to Richmond, Va.-based CSX and Norfolk, Va.-based Norfolk Southern.
In its earnings report, Norfolk Southern said strong rail traffic and tight expense controls offset higher fuel costs.
It said net income rose to $200.5 million, or $1.60 a share, from $176.9 million, or $1.37 a share, in the 1995 quarter. Sales rose 2 percent to $1.18 billion from $1.16 billion.
"Despite an extraordinary rise in fuel prices, we ended 1996 on a high note, setting records across the board," Goode said in a statement.
He cited strength in shipments of cars, coal and chemicals and noted the company's North American Van Lines trucking unit had its best operating earnings in nine years.
Transportation expenses actually fell 3 percent in the quarter despite higher fuel costs, Norfolk Southern said.
The results were about in line with expectations but Norfolk Southern stock rose $1.50 to $88.25 in midday trading on the New York Stock Exchange.
